page.title: Complement Clauses - Examples and Features
page.introduction: The various types of complement clauses shown in the trees represent the argument structure of the verb as well as its syntactic subcategorization. Therefore, there is some degree of cross-linguistic similarity in the types of clausal complements the verbs subcategorize for.

EnglishExample.exItem: First, consider verbs which take only a finite CP (or IP) complement, like:
I believe (that) Jill is my friend.
Jill insists (that) she is my friend.
I know (that) he likes me.

form.prompt: Think of any similar examples from your language and key them here:
form.instruction:
In the lexicon, add the feature makeC to the complementizer(s) so it will show up in the correct position in the tree structure.
Add the features sentential embedded_finite to the lexical entries for the main verbs in the examples. If one or more of your verbs require the complementizer to be present, also add the feature embedded_CP to those entries.

EnglishExample.exItem: Next, consider verbs which take either a finite CP (or IP) complement or a nonfinite IP complement, like:
I expect that Joe will come to the party.
I expect Joe to come to the party.

form.prompt: Think of any similar examples from your language and key them here:
form.instruction: Add the features sentential embedded_-question to the lexical entries for the main verbs in the examples.

EnglishExample.exItem: Now consider verbs which take a direct object as well as either a finite ot nonfinite complement, like:
I will persuade Joe that he should come to the party.
I will persuade Joe to come to the party.

form.prompt: Think of any similar examples from your language and key them here:
form.instruction: Add the feature sentential_with_object to the lexical entries for the main verbs in the examples.

EnglishExample.exItem: Some verbs only take a nonfinite IP complement, but the subject may be overt or dropped when it is coreferent with the main clause subject, as in:
I want to come to the party.
I want Joe to come to the party.

form.prompt: Think of any similar examples from your language and key them here:
form.instruction: Add the features sentential embedded_-finite embedded_IP to the lexical entries for the main verbs in the examples.

EnglishExample.exItem: Some verbs only take a nonfinite IP complement and the subject must be coreferent with the main clause subject and dropped, as in:
Joe tried to come to the party.
I tried to think of more examples.

form.prompt: Think of any similar examples from your language and key them here:
form.instruction: Add the features sentential embedded_-finite embedded_pro-drop embedded_IP to the lexical entries for the main verbs in the examples.

EnglishExample.exItem: Some verbs only take a nonfinite complement, but the complementizer 'for' is present when the embedded subject is overt, as in:
Joe would hate for Sue to be at the party.
Joe hates to dance.
I would like to be appreciated.

form.prompt: Think of any similar examples from your language and key them here:
form.instruction: Add the features sentential embedded_-finite embedded_IPpro-dropOrCP to the lexical entries for the main verbs in the examples.
form.prompt: Your language may also have other restrictions on embbeded clauses, such as the embbeded verb being in the subjunctive mood or in the perfective aspect. Key any of those examples here:
form.instruction: Add the feature sentential to the lexical entries for the main verbs in the examples. Also add the feature embedded_subjunctive or embedded_perfective if appropriate for your language. Other specific restrictions will need to be taken care of after completion of the starter kit.
